Currently, British people eat about four chocolate bars each week, which has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One new idea is the "extended line," where chocolate bars are turned into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who want something different.

However, cacao farmers are still struggling due to a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, remember the challenges faced by those who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a master in his craft. He still wants to try new things, like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he focuses on creating beautiful objects from shells. "Tell me if I am boring you," he says as he shows me his work in his apartment. There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is definitely passionate, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I love them so much. I never planned to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends suggested I have an exhibition so more people could see my art. They even talked to a gallery owner." This led to an exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition just opened yesterday. The prices for his work are high, around £2,000 for some decorations, but Cooke doesn’t mind giving up space on his wall for them.

There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Cooke says he has no control over the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else makes art like his, and the gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won’t be any more."

Cooke wishes he had started this work earlier in life because he believes he could have created even more amazing things. Although he still has many ideas, he feels limited physically compared to when he began. However, his work is very different from the common shell crafts found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he says, which has led him to create boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, small pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

He has developed his own methods and uses materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue bought in bulk, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he explains, but the detail and color in his work show that it is not random.

Cooke searches for beautiful, tiny shells not just on the beaches of Norfolk, but also in places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists that he only collects dead shells and responds to people who accuse him of damaging beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people walking on them much faster than I can collect them. The ones left behind are broken by the sea. I would never take shells with living creatures in them, but once they are empty, why shouldn’t I collect them?" His argument is strong, especially considering the beauty he creates from the shells he finds.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is a 15-year-old girl who is both a model and a student. When she is not traveling to exciting places or appearing on magazine covers, she is studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw shares more about Kira.

The receptionist at Kira's modeling agency told me, "I'm afraid Kira will be a little late." I thought to myself that I hoped the bad things I had read about models were not true. Words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent came to my mind. I worried about how late she would be. Would she be an hour late? Three hours? Or would she not come at all? What if she chose to go to the hairdresser instead of meeting me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to talk.

However, when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling, relaxed, and accompanied by her mother. She was not wearing expensive designer clothes but a simple black dress and trainers. She seemed friendly and down-to-earth, not at all selfish. Kira explained that all models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, and her mother looked proud of her daughter.

Kira seems a bit confused by her sudden fame, which is understandable since it was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter the modeling competition. "She saw the competition and said I should join," Kira recalled. "I said no, but she sent some photos anyway." When Kira learned she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen gave her the confidence to continue, and she performed very well. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London offered her work right away.

Now, Kira finds it challenging to balance her two lives as a model and a student. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some people at school are not kind. "They say I think too highly of myself," she said. This must be hard for Kira, as she is not a self-important person. She explained, "They think that because I became a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that has changed is that I am more confident, not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more."

Being a busy model affects her social life. The Select agency can call her at any time to offer her a job for the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll join them because I don't know my plans for the next day. I can't really make plans, and sometimes they get canceled, but my friends understand. They don’t complain that I am always busy with modeling."

Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a great career ahead of her, and not many people can say that before finishing their school exams. As I was about to end the interview with this remarkable girl, I asked her what she would like to do if she didn't have her beauty. She paused and said, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

**Father and Son Start Gold Rush**

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the hot lands of Africa in search of valuable metals. This father and son team—one an explorer and the other a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could hold up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated."

They have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions buried in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the best area of land to explore. After clearing away plants and finding pieces of gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission from landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running out of money. They have spent their savings on this dream and need to convince someone to invest £50,000 to dig a bit deeper to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, it looks doubtful, but we have a few people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread through the valleys, the excitement of gold began to attract the attention of local people as well as other gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourism, and residents are cautiously hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they are right, it would bring more people here, but I hope millions won’t come and damage the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has greatly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It’s adventurous and exciting, the thrill of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I’ll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited. Rachel says, "I can reach out and touch the two pilots." They are used to being in such a small space where they cannot stand up or move around, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and then three hours to return to the surface. If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can hit a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface, but Rachel thinks it would not be a pleasant journey.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, they found a large area of underwater volcanoes that were releasing black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She says, "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.'" This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This smoke comes out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.

Rachel recalls a frightening moment during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. She felt a huge bang as shock waves hit their vehicle and thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She thinks, "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before." Rachel studied the black smokers for three years for her PhD, and when she finally saw them in person, it was an amazing feeling.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind was confused by different train schedules, currencies, and languages. "Never again," I said as I returned home. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. All I needed to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month.

Sleeping in a train corridor is very different from sleeping in a regular bed. The movement of the train rocks you to sleep. Carrying all your things in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasteful habits, like burning socks that smell bad or throwing away finished books. However, this carefree way of traveling is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be forgotten along with your paperback book and socks. All you need is one of those tickets in your hand.

A ticket that lets young people travel through many countries in one day is special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize how much we could do with this ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But the idea of traveling non-stop was too exciting. There was always one more country to visit, and it didn’t cost us anything extra.

We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Rail travelers. We planned our own schedule and focused only on the sights we could easily see. This was a chance to avoid guided tours and do something different. I was proud that in many places, all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to enjoy ourselves, like most other Inter-Railers who shared the train corridors, food, water, money, and music with us.

The excitement of travel comes from arriving in a place that was just a name before. It feels like the city didn’t exist until the train arrives, and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by seeing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different attitudes and lifestyles can you really understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. While the train trip may not let you discover new things in the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is large, and Inter-Rail gives people a great chance to explore it, even if it doesn’t happen right away for everyone.

Text: 'There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and stuck wearing clothes that are not suitable for the weather. 

Airlines do not often share how many bags they lose, but it is common for travelers to be separated from their luggage at some point. Even the best airlines can make mistakes, and it is impossible for any airline to guarantee that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight, especially if your journey includes one or more flight changes.

Here is how the system works: Airlines require passengers to check in early, which gives enough time for luggage to go through the airport and be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to transfer between two flights, and these times are also extended to help with luggage transfers. Normally, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic problems can cause flight delays, which can lead to issues with the baggage system. 

Human error can also happen, such as when a destination label gets torn off. These problems can be worse at large airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London’s Heathrow airport served over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom had to transfer between Terminal 1 (for domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights).

Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. The chance of losing luggage when changing planes is higher at certain airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when transatlantic passengers connect to flights in Latin America.

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights whenever you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline for all your flights. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and make sure to label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, including your flight numbers.

If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

**The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing some shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, browns, and various shades of yellow from the sunlight, creating a calm atmosphere like the gentle sounds of water in the breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and gracefully, almost like a flash of light, and it is gone in an instant. However, its image stays in your mind, and its beauty is surprising for such a small bird.

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He feels a strong connection to this little bird, but he cannot explain exactly why. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is a bird that was once a moon goddess. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its lower body was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this story. Even though kingfishers have many shades of blue in their feathers, they do not have any blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light, making them appear blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the angle of the light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers love kingfishers. Their beautiful colors and the fact that they can be watched from a distance make them fascinating. Charlie's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just one meter away. However, it took him four more years to take his first good picture. During this time, the European kingfisher became a big part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream where kingfishers lived. Unfortunately, school took away some of his time with the birds, and he missed classes, calling himself an "academic failure." But his passion for this widespread kingfisher, which is the only one of its family that breeds in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He later worked as an assistant to the editor and eventually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, Charlie wants to make the perfect kingfisher film. "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. "I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks about the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still fascinates him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his connection with the kingfisher than what his work can show.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from New Conductors**

Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She ended up filling in for an absent assistant and was later asked to help with another opera. "I had to lead the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. I wasn't nervous. I have always felt good about standing in front of an orchestra." Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern works. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several projects.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after trying twice before. Looking back, he feels lucky about the timing: "If it had happened earlier, I would have been forgotten." The competition gave him many chances to perform and a role as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he struggles with being known only for the competition: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be worried." Fortunately, orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, which hired him after the competition, are inviting him back. If this doesn't happen, his career could suffer.

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of attention," she says. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Starting lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from much bigger people, which makes a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to consider the personalities of the singers."

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, says, "Conducting surprised me, but it fascinates me." He began as a musician in an opera house and worked with talented conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's *Agrippina* from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I tried my best to achieve that. People respect my skills as a musician. I learn from every experience I've had, both in musical style and performance. Now, I will do whatever people ask to discover what I enjoy."

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, a young assistant conductor, and told his agent about him. Now 32, Marshall quickly found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was a tough start. He even had to manage some relaxed professional musicians reading newspapers during the show: "I was firm with them. I always kept a clear beat and aimed for the best result. Many orchestral musicians I’ve seen don’t seem to need advice from a conductor. But I’m never afraid to express what I want. If people see you’re worried, it gets worse. I have never studied conducting formally, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been kind to me. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are thinking about taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to try out some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US and thought Fun Island would be boring in comparison. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the kids wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and nicer scenery. But the staff were very helpful, and we found it clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to relax. The park is beautifully designed, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There is something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still felt there was more to see. The kids loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes closed, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is also a lot of fun for younger children. The kids looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved when they found out they were too small to go on it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides isn’t boring. It is very clean, and the staff are great. When I couldn’t sit with both girls on one ride, a staff member kindly went with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am a bit of a coward, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children were a bit older, they might have found it a little boring, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we definitely felt that way. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is the main attraction, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride. Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even worse! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older kids went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were going home early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer-aided design business that makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine moved from London to the countryside when her children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Since she had experience with computers, her husband suggested she start a design business. It was hard at first and required a lot of money. Christine was careful with her spending and kept the bank manager informed. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if she wants. Her business is small, and most customers come to pick up their work.

B. **Maggy Sasanow** is a greetings card designer who works from home. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but after getting married, she moved to the countryside where such jobs were not available. So, she started her own business and now makes 50 different greetings cards that she sells to museums. She works in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. Maggy does not advertise; her business grows through word of mouth. She is cheaper than other artists, which helps her get work from London. Although she misses sharing ideas with others, she finds more benefits than drawbacks in her situation.

C. **Delia Turner** runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started her business eight years ago when it was growing. In two years, her income increased from £24,000 to £80,000, and she employed six full-time workers. However, due to a decline in the economy, she had to let them go, which was difficult because jobs are hard to find in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and works with women who also work from home. Delia has learned to lower her prices when needed and to look for new opportunities.

D. **Tessa Strickland** manages her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the area. Tessa enjoys the flexibility of working when she wants. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she often takes calls at unusual hours. The challenge is staying disciplined and closing the office door when needed. She publishes children's books from different cultures and collaborates with authors and artists. At first, she felt lonely because all her professional experience was in London.

E. **Meg Rivers** runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop that makes £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. She started her business ten years ago at home. Interested in health, she began making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients. Requests from friends and family led her to send cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made, and now she has a baker and an assistant. Meg no longer bakes herself; she focuses on managing the business. Her biggest challenge has been the financial side, as she did not have a lot of money to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their dad makes musical instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins, who are schoolteachers in South Wales, wanted to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, but found it too expensive. John thought about making one himself. He discovered the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and took evening classes for about three years. 

After trying to make violins and violas, John finally made his first cello. Paul, now 28, remembers that it turned out really well. John made another cello for him later, which Paul used until a few months ago. John has now retired from teaching and works full-time as a craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. He was very proud to sell one to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul began with the piano: "As soon as I could reach the keys, I played," he recalls. He also tried the violin because his dad played the viola and needed another violin for his music group. However, Paul preferred the cello after being inspired by a cellist in his dad's group. 

Huw, now 22, says their parents were supportive but not pushy. He felt encouraged by Paul's success rather than threatened by it. Huw is now starting to make a name for himself as a pianist and composer.

Paul has achieved a lot with the cello his dad made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. He played his father's cello until last year, but now he has a new cello on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. 

Paul jokes that his dad's cello might need 50 to 100 years to sound as powerful as his new one, which is already 304 years old. Soon, Paul will perform on television with his new cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto. However, he won't be able to watch himself because he will be playing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall that evening. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust to care for its beautiful areas.

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills. "You are always dealing with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies," he explains. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training. 

Gareth says, "It helps that I still farm with my parents. I can understand farmers and their problems. They can't trick me!" His farming background also helps him handle the physical work of the job, like building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers picking flowers and collecting butterflies when he was younger. He now realizes that farming has changed the countryside. "It's not the farmers' fault; they were just following government advice," he says.

When Gareth started his job, farmers and conservationists often disagreed. Both sides wanted things done their own way. Now, they are talking and understanding each other better. "We are at a point where we can bring them together," Gareth explains. 

Gareth's work includes conservation, allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and meeting with tenant farmers. "My job is to make sure tasks are completed efficiently and without problems. I enjoy seeing projects finished, but I spend about half my time on reports and paperwork," he shares. 

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys every moment, especially talking to the public. However, he finds some visitors frustrating. "Some people come in, demand everything, and leave as if they own the place. It annoys me to be nice to them!" he admits. But Gareth believes that common sense is key.

If you have common sense and enjoy outdoor work, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. However, don't expect a job to open up in the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, which is normal for her as she prepares for the World Championships next month. She taught at a local school and then had a training session in a supermarket parking lot. 

I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on what I'm doing—my movements and my feet—that I don’t notice anything else. I might see cars slowing down out of the corner of my eye, but that’s it."

Kendra said, "My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships. I have a strict schedule to get fit." This will be her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a good game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra mentioned, "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra knows the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard just to lose. But once the game is over, we become friends again."

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. Kendra said, "It’s important that we all think and train like world-class players. As captain, I need to have a strong mindset and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my team."

Kendra explained, "From the start of my netball career, I have planned everything carefully. I decided a while ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents help a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be difficult to know the best way to support their gift. Some parents may not realize their child's needs until they show frustration through difficult behavior. While most schools can help children who excel in academic subjects, musically talented children need special support that may not be available in regular schools, especially if music is not a priority there. 

Children who are musically gifted, or whose talents are encouraged by their parents or teachers, may benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established recently. These schools provide a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen to develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend about one third to one half of their day on music activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their first and second instruments), playing in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program that focuses on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages. However, students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with small class sizes and a high number of teachers compared to students. Most children at these schools live there full-time, which allows them to spend their formative years with others who share their interests and goals.

What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; fees for boarding students range from £12,000 to £17,000 a year. However, each school tries to help parents of talented children with scholarships and financial aid. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a strict environment. They emphasize that their goal is to help children become well-rounded individuals.

It is clear that separating musically gifted children from a young age can create stress. Some early signs of musical talent may fade during the teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, all specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide help when needed. 

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some worry about the limited academic program, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their academic needs are not met. 

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before considering a specialist music education. Children who are also academically gifted may do well in a regular school with a strong music program or by combining a normal school schedule with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, as well as opportunities to play in orchestras and chamber music groups. However, this option may not be possible for families living far from London or other major cities.

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house provides many of her subjects. It is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower borders along the path that goes from east to west are full of colors, shapes, and structures. This beauty is partly because of the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' for some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in the way flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, you think they are boring, but they keep changing."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening then; I didn't like garden flowers because they looked like fake ones sold in some shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they seem just as comfortable in her garden as they do in China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don’t cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects to paint, she has found it hard to spend time in the garden recently. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never done, says Sarah Sutherland-Pilch. This is her second year as a chalet girl. Sarah, 24, is from West Sussex and works in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University, where she studied French and History of Art. She sees being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to meet successful people," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. "They get a full breakfast - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m."

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but does not sleep because she says it would be a mistake. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning." Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great, but some weeks are not as good for various reasons."

Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. They often start at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar. However, Sarah does not stay out too late on Saturday because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day," she says, "when you really don’t want to cook breakfast feeling tired."

On Sundays, Sarah starts work earlier than usual because breakfast for the guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans quickly. "We just clean everything - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get ready for the next guests." If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. "Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions. I think the mountain air affects them."

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or equipment and then gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again, and she might chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper who spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. She found it hard to choose what to wear because she usually wears a uniform at the zoo. Her day started in a photo studio and then she went to press previews before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and she felt rushed at the magazine when she could have been quietly cuddling an animal. Some people on the fashion team seemed stressed, but Mandie’s job is not very stressful. During a fashion shoot in the afternoon, she laughed at the thought that she would normally be cleaning cages or handling rats. She is interested in how magazines work, but she loves her job at the zoo and wants to stay there.

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. She arrived wearing leather boots and dark blue trousers, but the zoo gave her a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because she got very dirty. While petting an elephant, she thought about Mandie probably packing clothes at the magazine. By five o'clock, she felt dirty but had a wonderful day. She could see herself working with elephants in Africa after she retires from fashion.

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the team from the gardening show Ground Force. She was very excited to meet the team, especially Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter. She enjoyed being outside because she sometimes doesn’t see daylight due to her shifts. Although the work was hard, it was fun. She thought she was strong, but felt weak compared to the team. She realized that landscape gardening involved a lot of physical work and planning. She is more enthusiastic than effective at gardening, so she doesn’t plan to leave her nursing job.

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener from Ground Force, spent a day at Hammersmith Hospital. He made beds and handed out medicine. He thought he might faint during some tasks, but he was surprised that it didn’t bother him. He enjoyed the friendship among the nurses and felt it was very different from his usual male work environment. He felt that his job was not as important as nursing. Although his day at the hospital was not easy, it gave him a great sense of satisfaction.

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, worked with Ryanair as cabin crew for a day. When she put on the uniform, she felt different and noticed that people looked up to her. Before the flight, their supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which she already knew from her fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, she handed out magazines and felt self-conscious as everyone stared at her. On the way back, they had 80 schoolchildren on board who wouldn’t sit still, and she wished she was back in the gym with one sensible adult.

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was nervous about this swap because she doesn’t exercise. She was surprised by how much attention trainers give to one person. In her job, she meets 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, she noticed that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. She wouldn’t change her job for this, but it inspired her to join a gym and try to be healthier.

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and crosses into Italy. It takes you past some of the most beautiful sea views. No matter the weather or the time of year, the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are looking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the stunning views.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and was sent to stay with an aunt. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am very grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey was wonderful as we traveled through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a round-the-world trip and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was not reliable; we were just told to be ready on a certain day. We heard that the driver would wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train arrived, many people rushed to get on, and some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people have favorite memories of trains from when they were children, but that’s not true for me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old train line that volunteers had kept in good condition. That’s where my love for steam trains started. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stopped. Everything was still the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

**Trying to Get Published?**

If you want to publish your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story or book. Where should I send it?" One of the first things you need to do is research the market and learn about publishers while also improving your writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the publishing world.

No matter what type of writing you do, you should learn about the markets you want to reach. The best way to do this is by reading as much as you can about relevant topics. Visit your local library, bookstores, and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are currently accepting. 

As time goes on, you need to keep updating your knowledge because new publications are always coming out. Editors change jobs, and magazines can change their focus. Publishers are always looking for new writers, so you need to know what they want.

At first, you might not be sure what you want to write. For example, if you think you want to write short love stories, the first step is to find out which magazines publish love stories. This market is quite limited these days, so get as many recent copies of those magazines as you can. Learn about the types of stories they buy and who their readers are. These readers have specific expectations, and the editor wants to meet those needs.

Writers often ask me, "This story has been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I never want to discourage anyone. However, it is likely that the work is not ready for publication. I try to give honest feedback while staying positive. The problem is that many new writers are too eager to send out their work before they are ready. If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. This almost never happens. When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have been in publishing or journalism for several years before achieving it.

When you finally send out your work for the first time, start writing more stories while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to see yourself as a writer. This will help you become more confident and fluent in your writing. Instead of giving up on your stories, work on improving them. 

I also recommend not showing your work to others, especially in the beginning. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before finding success. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby, or join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.

**No Title**

On the last day of a bad year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people waiting than I expected. The usual clean and bright feeling of the station was gone. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students had their bags all over the floor. 

A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers. He looked well-off: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought it would be nice to talk to her. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" 

"Well, I'm going north," she replied, "but to Philadelphia? No, I'm going to New York." 

"Thanks, anyway," he said and moved to the next bench. Now I was really paying attention. 

"Ma'am," I heard him ask an old lady, "are you traveling to Philadelphia?" When she said she was going to Wilmington, he just walked on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform as if I was focused on the train. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me, but I understood why he didn’t. He probably thought I looked unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then went to the other end of the waiting area. 

By now, he looked very stressed. "Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She looked up from her book. She was in her thirties, maybe thirty-five, older than me. She looked like a school teacher. 

"Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." 

"Could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" 

They announced my train, and people started moving toward Gate E, older couples pulling their wheeled bags behind them like pets. Then I heard the man talking. 

"My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia and didn’t know what to do." 

The woman nodded sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet and waited to see where this was going. 

"So I told her to stay put in the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport." 

That sounded suspicious! Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? 

"Why don’t you go yourself?" the woman asked. 

"I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." 

That seemed like a weak excuse to me. Also, it was too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one, the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn’t feel what was inside! From where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. Be careful, lady, I thought silently.

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes that everyone gets a chance in life. His chance was to run a restaurant, and Gary's chance was to cook.

When John first saw the restaurant, it was in very bad condition, but he thought it was perfect for his plans. This experience reminded him of his childhood. He remembers being sad when his mother went to work in a factory and he was left alone. Because of this, he wanted to make sure his family had time together. His wife took care of the children and managed the finances while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made time for family meals. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become very confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.

Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into the corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to earn pocket money. He started with small jobs and by the age of ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which meant he had a lot of money at school. He was very disciplined and would wake up even before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John was happy to see Gary working.

Although Gary was not very good in school, he was excellent in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could prepare over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would work in catering because he had a natural talent. When Gary needed to do work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one thing at a time, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." John also told Gary that he needed to achieve his goals by the age of 30, or it might be too late.

At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, while other students were just starting, Gary quickly chopped all his vegetables and sliced the meats. He even helped his classmates. Everyone is amazed at how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become, and John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary that if you want something, you have to work hard for it because nothing is given for free. Gary has recognized the opportunities he has and has taken full advantage of them.

As parents, we talk to our children as they grow up, and even if they only remember a little of what we say, we should be happy. John sees that Gary listens and learns from him, which makes him proud.

**Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult. The best way to find one is through personal connections. If you know someone who knows someone leaving a flat, that can help. But if, like Jo, you just arrived in Dublin, you don’t have those connections. So, Jo had to stay in a hostel and search for a flat. For her, Dublin felt very unfamiliar. She felt nervous when she took the train to start her new job there. She didn’t question why she was going; everyone at school expected her to leave her small town. They all wanted to escape and experience life. Some of her classmates had moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo’s mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm because they are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn’t know they were still talking about her while she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to her job at the post office and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive.

There wasn’t a line for this flat because it was more about finding a "Third Girl Wanted" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a simple red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs, and as Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. 

"Desperate place," she told Jo. "They’re both awful. Common as dirt." 

"Oh," Jo replied and continued up. 

"Hello," said the girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that stuck-up girl leaving? I can’t stand her kind." 

"What did she do?" Jo asked. 

"She didn’t do anything. She just looked around, made a face, and giggled, saying, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 

Pauline, wearing a very colorful shirt, looked like a punk. Jo had seen punks on O'Connell Street but had never talked to one before. 

"I'm Jo, I work at the post office and I called about the flat," she said. 

Nessa said they were about to have tea and brought out three mugs: one with "Nessa," one with "Pauline," and one labeled "Other." 

"We’ll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," she said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside areas, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of dolphin populations.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, sensitive to human feelings, and they inspire us with dreams of freedom in the ocean. Our affection for dolphins has been supported by TV shows. First, there was Flipper, and now there is Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas today.

The number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think that such popular animals would be protected by laws and cared for in special marine areas. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a major wildlife disaster.

There are forty different types of dolphins around the world. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the open sea and are seen in small groups. We know very little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be seen often near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were once found along the Channel coast and in rivers in Britain, including the Thames. Now, they can only be found in a few places like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress, like skin injuries.

It is hard to know exactly why dolphin numbers are decreasing. Overfishing is a major problem, as it reduces fish populations and threatens local fishing industries. Porpoises and dolphins need to find food quickly. If fish are removed from one area, they may not have enough time to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that are either left floating or pulled quickly through the water. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died after being caught in these nets.

Dolphins can also store harmful substances in their bodies. For example, pesticides can build up in their fat. Female dolphins produce milk that contains these poisons, which can harm their young. There has been at least one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s poisoned milk.

Another serious threat to dolphins comes from human activity. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their environment. Noise pollution from ships and oil drilling travels much better in water than in air, which can disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced, especially when life feels chaotic and fast-paced. You might be tired of reading about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to.

Exercise helps improve your muscle tone and can quickly change your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It also prevents muscle imbalances that can lead to injuries. You can see quick improvements in areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. Additionally, exercise is good for your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You may have heard these benefits many times, but here’s something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can help you sleep better. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some medical conditions. 

If you’re not convinced yet, just remember that common sense tells us exercise is good for us. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. If you’re unsure about what exercises are right for you, it’s a good idea to talk to your doctor.

Good posture is essential for improving your body shape. If you have poor posture, it can make you look and feel less energetic and can lead to health problems. To improve your posture, imagine that a helium balloon is pulling the top of your head up towards the sky. This will help you lift your chest and breathe better, while also making your body look slimmer.

Stretching your muscles is important because it improves flexibility and helps you move easily. It also helps you maintain good posture and prevents injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. Stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine, and you should do it slowly and carefully.

The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their comfortable homes for months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it can be very hard to find them. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost constant rain. This has caused many unexpected problems. Newman said they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their teamwork has produced some of the best wildlife films on TV, including a popular film about leopards. While that film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time following the shy jackal.

Traveling film-makers have been exploring the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman during one of his rare meetings with other people at a safari lodge. He said, "We do have occasional arguments, but we usually get over them quickly." Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they both understand the animals in a similar way. 

"When we are moving, we have to set up our tents each night. But now we are working from a fixed camp. We leave at 5 a.m. each morning, so we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask." Their daily meals consist of pre-packed food that they heat and serve. "It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can sometimes be stressful," Newman said. 

Their life can be tough, but being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions. One lioness would often go off alone, but when she returned, she would greet all the other lions and eventually come to greet their car too.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they teamed up to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months in one location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. 

Newman said, "Amanda and I built a good working relationship from the start because we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create a film that captures the true spirit of the place and the animals, and that touches people's hearts. I believe if you can make people feel something, that is much better than just making them think."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, which was normal for her as she prepared for the World Championships next month. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I was surprised to learn about her training location. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus so much on my movements and my feet that I don’t notice anything else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s it."

Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships. I follow a strict schedule to be as fit as possible." This will be her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a good game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra believes they have always won against them, but she knows they will be a tough team to play. "They have a lot of talent," she said. The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra knows the Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years Kendra has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive now. "You don’t train hard to lose," Kendra said. "But after the final whistle, we become friends again."

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. "It’s important that we all think and train like world-class players," Kendra explained. As captain, she believes it’s essential to have a strong mindset and to lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team."

Kendra has planned her netball career carefully from the start. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes, knowing her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, Rachel says, "The space is so small that I can touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface."

"If there is a problem and we need to get to the top quickly, we can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface. No one has tested it yet, but I don’t think it would be a pleasant journey."

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space.

Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. "We went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There is a large area of underwater volcanoes that release black smoke. This is where the Atlantic Ocean is very active. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano."

When she is not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.' This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It flows out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

"The only time I was scared was during my first dive with the Americans. We were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we were so relieved - we were still alive!"

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel amazed. I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D., and when I finally saw them in person, it was an incredible feeling."

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, and how we speak, including our speed, volume, and tone of voice, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she noticed a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing but decided it would make her late, and she believes it is important to be on time. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says that candidates who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People often say that what matters is inside, but in an interview, you should try to present yourself in the best way possible. However, many people overlook the importance of a professional appearance.

For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but did not even get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed her work performance should matter more than her appearance.

Body language and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message about feelings comes from the words we use, 38% comes from our voice, and a surprising 55% comes from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. So, make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and had a great interview. She was offered the job immediately. However, she reacted with too much excitement. Once her boss saw how happy she was, he knew she would accept the offer, so he gave her a lower salary than she expected. She believes she could have negotiated for a better salary if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what we say and how we say it can affect the success of an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can provide information about the company’s activities. Mentioning an area that interests you during the interview can show your interest in the company.

Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and highlight important points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**
