**Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 different types of grasses, and they can be found in every part of the earth. Grass is the only type of flowering plant that can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way.

Grass can recover quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the soil instead of from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one area. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, providing fresh food for them.

Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion. She recently won this title at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who run a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university.

After finishing university, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to go to many industry events but could not afford the designer clothes she liked. To solve this, she started making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends saw her creations, they asked her to make clothes for them too. 

Kal then found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. Her clothes became very popular, and nothing was returned. This success encouraged her to leave her advertising job, take out a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear brand. 

Kal's parents were supportive of her decision to change careers, which made her very happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal feels grateful for her journey and says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

**Tom Cruise**

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. However, his life has not always been easy. As a young boy, Tom was shy and found it hard to make friends, but he loved acting in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, the film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became very successful and was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each film. Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometers. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. He gave her some milk and started to ask questions. He called his last customers, but they had not lost a cat. Since it was getting late, he took Bo home for the night and the next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner was also looking for her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he remembered the name of the company. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.'

**The Ghan Train**

Mark Ottaway took a train journey from Darwin, in northern Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train travels across Australia, from the warm northern coast through vast deserts to the cooler Southern Ocean. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but it is known for being late.

The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s, with a line built from Adelaide to Alice Springs. However, heavy flooding often made it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished just a few months before my trip. The railway was designed for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a fast train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is very good.

Originally, the railway was built to transport goods, not passengers. It was believed that sending goods from Europe to southern Australia through Darwin and the train would save time and money compared to shipping around the continent. It is rare to complete a transcontinental railway, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south railway.

As I waited to board the Ghan, I noticed that everyone was excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian retirees, and they were eager to get on the train. Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip in the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and enjoyed the beautiful sunset.

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers stop their journey there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting; there is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But on the third day, at dawn, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was ending, and even though the train did not meet all the promises made in advertisements, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

**Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt shares his experience of climbing Ben Nevis for the first time.

It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We chose a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is six hundred meters high, probably the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the "Carries," which are large bowls cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes on Ben Nevis because the snow can be very hard, making it feel like walking on ice. 

Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, including lights to attract attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started our climb. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge.

The path quickly became steep, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest member of the group, so I had to take more breaks. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I arrived, they would start again. I promised myself that I would train better before my next climb.

After climbing 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we finally reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. Unfortunately, we were not lucky that day because a mist had come down.

Getting back down to camp can be just as hard as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we took turns reading the map. That first time, I only felt I really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top!

**Anna's New School**

This week has been very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood to build it, just like our old school, but this one is also designed to be environmentally friendly. The school took many months to build, and we watched the process. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, but it also meant that some nice open space was lost. The noise from the building machines was very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms that are very big—much bigger than the old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and large changing rooms that we can't wait to use when our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice that there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from everyone inside—the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep the heat inside, and it also keeps the sound in, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that the school roof has a tree on it! The builders put it there after finishing the roof because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for the lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so big that you can see it from far away! We took some pictures to put on our website.

Even though we are already using the school, some parts are still being finished. For example, we are putting on a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now that we are here!

**No Title**

A month ago, I had no idea that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below me, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place where we stayed was not great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air.

On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with their friend Amanda. We all came from different places and did not know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we were not sure how.

Half of us went caving in the morning, while the others went rock climbing. We switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out—covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**

On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn’t know what to do. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I felt very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried.

A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what had happened. He kindly gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I explained the situation to the bus driver, he said I could keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He told me they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me.

I was amazed to get my handbag back with everything inside still there. I want to thank everyone who helped me that day. I really appreciate their kindness and honesty.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Sharks**

Sharks are some of the most frightening animals in our oceans. They are very good at hunting underwater because they can see well and feel movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat.

Although sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they hardly ever sleep. Also, if sharks are turned upside down, they can stop moving completely. This is a useful technique for researchers who need to study sharks. It helps them learn more about these interesting creatures.

Joining the Kirov Ballet

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. On my first day of ballet class, I felt nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came up to me and asked questions in Russian. I tried to speak in Russian, and then they started talking to me in English, so we could understand each other. 

Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I can understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mom stayed with me, and when she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home one night because I felt lonely. 

The classes in Russia are much harder than at my ballet school in England, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This helps me feel confident that I can meet the school’s high standards. In the evenings, I like to watch my favorite movies on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before they finish. 

Now that I have settled in, I feel at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10 degrees Celsius, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room is warm and cozy. 

Right now, we are getting ready for a new production, and there is also a competition for young dancers that I plan to enter. I feel very lucky to be here.

**THE ICEHOTEL**

For many years, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. However, in winter, the few people living there enjoyed the snow and ice by themselves. By the end of the 1980s, people started to see the dark and cold winter as a good thing. 

In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a specially built igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, located on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, a group of foreign guests decided to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was created. Today, it is famous around the world.

When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from many countries come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As each part is finished, it opens to visitors and guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is completed in December, and each week after that, a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is fully finished. Because the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural winter materials, the completion date can change depending on the weather.

In spring, as the weather gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius, no matter how cold it is outside. Guests receive winter clothing like warm overalls, hats, and gloves as part of their stay. It is also a good idea for guests to bring sweaters, scarves, and plenty of woollen socks. They should choose shoes that are a bit larger than normal to fit the thick socks.

If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, woollen socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items along with your booking, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in. The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange bus transport from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle, a new furniture shop, had to close shortly after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop's regular hours will be from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had planned to stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening.

A police officer who was called to the shop said: "The police knew a large crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The shop quickly became full, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly until there was space for them. Another problem was that there was a long line of cars trying to get to the parking lot. I couldn't believe that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the shop. This blocked the road completely."

One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the shop, said: "I waited in line for three hours, and I didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice because it wasn't safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I don't want to wait in line again."

**Membership**

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of the most active arts organizations in Britain.

**Society Magazines**

We produce several great magazines, including the popular *Short Story Review*. This magazine features short stories by some of Britain's best writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work published. Another magazine, *Short Story News*, includes interviews with writers and has information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing community. You can find articles from recent issues by following the links on our website.

**National Short Story Competition**

We organize the National Short Story Competition, which is the largest competition of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and older, and you can submit short stories on any topic. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no entry fee for Society members (non-members pay £5). The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will receive a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories.

**Education**

For nearly thirty years, the Society has worked with schools, helping children and teachers with new ideas and building confidence in writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 and is open to writers aged 11-18. All winners receive book prizes and are invited to a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. It is a relaxed and stylish place with freshly cooked vegetarian food, great coffee, and cold drinks. It is perfect for looking through the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is located in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**

We have members all over the world, and anyone aged 18 or older can join. If you want to become a member of The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

**Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where competitors dive to great depths on just one breath of air. In 2003, she made history by becoming the first person to dive 120 meters into the ocean and return to the surface without help. A year earlier, she had dived deeper but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, making her the first woman to break a world record previously held by a man.

A team of fourteen safety divers watched her dive from different depths. After some serious accidents involving other divers, some people say free-diving is too dangerous. However, Tanya believes that safety is the most important thing, followed by training. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya keeps the same training schedule no matter what she is preparing for. Two-thirds of her training is done in the gym, while the rest is split between the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees. Instead, she prefers fast walking to build her fitness.

When she practices diving, she usually travels away from home. She aims to do fourteen dives over four weeks, taking a rest day between each dive. It is important for her not to get tired, as this could ruin her preparation. When she is not training for an event, Tanya often makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research projects and films.

Tanya grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, where she loved swimming and exploring rock pools to see sea life. She says her life now feels like living her childhood dreams. Because she is well-known in some countries, she believes people listen to her when she talks about environmental issues. Looking to the future, Tanya, who is now in her thirties, plans to keep breaking her own world records. Since she started free-diving at twenty-five, she is eager to continue in the sport for many more years.

**CARTOON FILMS**

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the screen. New ideas and advanced computer programs are making cartoons exciting again for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, many in the film industry thought cartoons were only for children. However, a few directors had original ideas that showed cartoons could be fun for both adults and children. 

Not every cartoon film was successful, though. For example, *The Black Cauldron* did not do well because it was too scary for children and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started to make a lot of money again.

New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first role on television. 

"I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always dreamed of playing her. 

Before starting university, I took a year off to travel. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me to say they were planning to make the book into a TV show. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised at first, but she sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. 

Filming started a week after university began, so I asked for permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned to university, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on the essays I had missed. I didn’t tell my university friends about the filming, but they found out and thought it was amazing. It was a wonderful experience, and I feel very lucky. 

After university, I definitely want to make acting my career. I am not from an acting family, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I have tried for other TV roles but haven’t received any offers yet. I’m not sure how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. 

When filming ended, I didn’t know what to do next. Since then, I have acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven’t been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I am going to Greece for the summer with friends."

**No Title**

When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough money to feed my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a fast-growing international company. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of this knowledge is in this book. I believe our company has valuable lessons about running a successful business while staying true to our beliefs.

This is not a typical business book, and it is not just about my life. The main message is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with love, and it can help others. In both business and life, I want to have fun, feel like I am part of a family, and be excited by new experiences. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way.

Now, this book shares my ideas with the world. I hope to show that there are no limits to our 'family' and to what we can achieve. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

Jules Verne operates a 'hotel ship' on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, all with outside views and private bathrooms. On the ship, which has air-conditioning, you will find a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** You will leave London Heathrow in the early evening and arrive in Oporto. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

**Day 2:** After sightseeing in Oporto in the morning, you will return to the ship and sail to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will continue up the river. In the early evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, known for its port wine. At dinner, you can enjoy delicious local food and drink.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will travel by bus to the ancient town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum that used to be a palace. The museum has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. After the visit, you will return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. You will return to Tua by coach, enjoying the sights along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the best views in the Douro Valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take the Douro Valley railway for a scenic ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.

**Day 7:** You will visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, you will sail down the river to Oporto and spend the night on board the Lady Ivy May.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with enough time for sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

**HONEY**

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey.

In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey so much that they used it as payment. Today, honey is produced and eaten all over the world. Research shows that honey can help reduce tiredness and improve athletic performance. However, honey is not just food; it can also help with sore throats and is used in many skin and hair-care products.

**Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a region in Britain, and has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it an important center for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated 800 years since it received a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and to govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second city of England. It continued to grow for the next 300 years, becoming wealthier and famous for having as many churches as there are weeks in a year and as many pubs as there are days in a year. Nowadays, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing number of students and its success as a commercial center (it is the largest center for insurance services outside London), Norwich now offers many entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and various arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team known as 'The Canaries', which wears green and yellow, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's new attractions is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, the people of Norwich lived with a large hole in the middle of their city while builders worked on the main car park. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to create a park on the roof of the Mall, complete with beautiful water features and many trees. The local people are happy that the old open market still exists in the city center, next to the new development. Both areas continue to thrive, showing that Norwich has successfully combined the best of the old and the new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, which lasts for nine days each year. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. It started with about twelve hot-air balloons taking off from a parking lot in the city. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected to join the event at its new location outside the city.

**What to See**

The pilots communicate with each other using radios, and they all light up the burners of their balloons at the same time. This event is called "balloon glows," and it is a great chance to take amazing photos. To see the glows, you should arrive just after dark or before 5:30 am. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in many sizes and colors, with some shaped like animals or cartoon characters, as well as popular products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will really enjoy it!

In the afternoon, you can also take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies that offer rides. Another option is to ride the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, which is the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a great view of the festival.

There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the first night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a local wind pattern that creates perfect conditions for balloon flying. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentler winds at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by going up or down.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival. Wear several layers of thin clothing because it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you will need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, don’t forget your camera. If you use film, make sure to bring high-speed film for evening and night photos.

The Eden Project

Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the most popular tourist attractions in the UK. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many everyday products come from plants, such as wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. More than 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always humid because of a large waterfall. Another zone mimics the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone soon.

Some people have said they do not like this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don’t understand why. It is amazing to have 500 pages of original writing for just £6.99. Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by well-known writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, many lesser-known writers have written mainly about food. I recommend you avoid reading Jane Harris's Those Nails right after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset you! 

The collection also features great work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are excerpts from novels that are still being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Additionally, there is a small amount of non-fiction, including a funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers and an extraordinary piece by Ursula Owen about her life. Overall, this is an exceptional collection, and I am excited to see what next year's edition will bring.

**The Best Age to Learn the Violin**

Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher, believes that the best age to start learning the violin is between three and six years old. She says this is when children are discovering the world around them. Margaret, who lives in London, usually teaches children who are three or four years old, but she sometimes makes exceptions for eager five-year-olds.

When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children’s five-year-old friends. Margaret teaches her students in groups. Each group has about twelve students, and they have lessons for one hour every two weeks. In addition, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents are also required to attend the classes because it is important for them to be involved in their children's learning.

From the very first lessons, students learn to play music by ear. They do not start reading music until they have been playing for several years. For a long time, there is a big difference between how well they can play and how well they can read music. Margaret explains that her teaching method is not meant to create great violinists. She often suggests that students who do very well should leave her class and learn the violin using more traditional methods.

**Moonshine**

The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. "Here Again" is a follow-up to their previous CD, "The Waves." There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson has also joined the band as the new drummer.

From the first song on the CD, which is a dance tune, it is clear that the band is moving away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will surprise many fans. Either of them could easily become a hit single because they are excellent. 

Singer Rob Letchford has a chance to show how talented he is, hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded these songs before he had problems with his throat. Because of this, the band had to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets does not need to worry, as all the concerts will be rescheduled as soon as Rob recovers.)

On this CD, Moonshine shows they can create great music in different styles, from the slow songs we know to the dance tracks that make you want to move. However, I felt that they placed their best songs at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as good. Despite this, "Here Again" is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.

**San Francisco**

San Francisco is located on the northern California coast. The first Europeans to find this area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a beautiful natural harbor, it was discovered by land, not by sea.

In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The wealthiest people were those who owned banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill.

Today, many tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to visit the old prison there.

**SAMUEL PEPYS**

The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting look at everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important events of that time, such as diseases, an enemy navy coming up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also shares personal stories, including his mistakes—like often falling asleep in church or looking at pretty girls. 

He talks about his home life, including arguments with his wife and how they made up, as well as his worries about her health. Besides reading, he enjoyed music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. Pepys was a busy man with many important jobs; he was a Member of Parliament and the President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work with the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**

In the past, people did not think much about whether shoes were comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people tied around their ankles to keep warm. Today, we still use leather, but we also have shoes made from materials like silk, plastic, and cotton, depending on current fashion trends. 

It was only about 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. 

In the past, all shoes were made by hand. Now, while some shoemakers still use traditional methods, most shoes are made by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines helped the shoe industry produce many more shoes at lower prices, making them available to more people.

**No Title**

When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women get into running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to help them feel confident about it. So, I started a running club for women in my area because I was frustrated with how some race organizers think. They often say there are not enough women in running, but they also use this as a reason not to provide separate changing rooms.

I put up posters, and 40 women of all ages and fitness levels joined. Most of them were interested in losing weight, but I don’t think they had thought much about running before. If they did, they imagined it as painful training. They didn’t see it as a chance to chat and smile while running in beautiful places, like by a river.

At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned about healthy eating and staying fit from other runners. I wanted to do something for women in running, and it has been a joy to see their progress—almost as much as they have enjoyed it themselves.

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people came to Alaska hoping to get rich. New towns were built quickly, and one of these towns was called Iditarod, which means "far, distant place." In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska.

In the summer, supplies could be delivered to these towns by boat. However, in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it hard to reach them. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for dog teams pulling sleds. These teams delivered mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail became known as the Iditarod Trail. It took a team of dogs about three weeks to travel across Alaska. They stopped at "roadhouses" where the drivers could sleep and eat, along with their dogs.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced boats and dog teams as the main way to transport goods. However, in 1925, the dogs became famous again when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The disease could be treated, but the closest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and no one was sure if they could fly in such cold weather. The only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away on a trip. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine instead.

The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. Twenty dog teams completed the trip in just six days. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who had come to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to find the way through the heavy snow, and Togo proved to be a great guide. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, refused to go further and saved the team from falling into icy water. Thanks to their efforts, the diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous journey in 1925. This race is called the Iditarod and is known as "The Last Great Race on Earth."

**Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is located in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit each year to see one of the most unique hotels in Europe. In this hotel, everything is made of ice, including the rooms where you eat, drink, and sleep. You can even have a wedding there! The bar is also made of ice, so it is not a good idea to put hot drinks on it.

The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to keep warm in the cold. If needed, they can also get suitable outdoor clothing. The hotel lasts for only six months because it melts in the summer, and every winter, it is rebuilt. Building the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.

**Maria Mutola**

In 1988, Maria Mutola was playing football as the only girl on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." This story was in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported other African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her kicking a ball outside the football club. He quickly realized that she was very fast.

"He talked to me about athletics. I didn’t understand what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs hurt a lot." But Jose spoke to her parents and convinced them that she could be successful and that this could help their family. They agreed to let him take her away to train.

In 1991, she finally accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had said no before because she knew she would miss her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She said, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were amazing, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs, and for most of the year, she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.

**The Skywalk**

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Many people visit Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and mostly to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and it is even better because of the Skywalk. The Skywalk is 1,219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform made of glass, so you can see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. The Skywalk opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of people have visited it. You must wear special covers over your shoes to protect the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like flying high in the air, like a bird.

**THE ROCKIES**

The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the Northwest and are only a few hundred miles from the center in the southern areas. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are still very beautiful. There are many roads that go through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. 

You can start your journey from Vancouver, which is one of the most beautiful cities in Canada. This city is located by the water and near the mountains, allowing people to ski just 15 minutes by car from the city center. 

In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver every day for the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still an exciting adventure. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you will see some of the best views at night.

**ZOOS**

People have kept animals in zoos for over 3,000 years. The first big zoo was called the Gardens of Intelligence, opened by the rulers of China. In the past, animals in zoos were trained to perform for visitors, but this is no longer done. Now, the main purpose of zoos is to let people see animals behaving naturally.

Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with zoos. Supporters believe that zoos help us learn about the natural world and allow us to see wild animals up close. They think these experiences would not be possible without zoos.

On the other hand, some people do not support zoos. They believe it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also argue that in poorly managed zoos, animals may live in dirty conditions and eat the wrong food.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like my band to bright T-shirts. We may not have looked like professional adult bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of our playing was amazing, especially since we are all so young. Players from each band even made up new tunes right on stage. It was exciting to watch, but it was even better when my band played!  

We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join gets in—only about half of the students. However, anyone who is eager to play can attend jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I have been to a couple and learned a lot.  

Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it is because pop music is not challenging enough for serious music lovers like me. I find jazz exciting because it feels both new and old at the same time. You can create your own music, but you also feel connected to its history, as you play on stage like great jazz performers did before you. My school is very lucky because we have great teachers and supportive parents. Without them, we would not get far with our music!

**Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain at any time between November and March. However, it does not rain often. When it does rain, the city's water pipes cannot handle the sudden floods, which can turn the streets into rivers. Many winters have been dry recently, so when it finally rains, the local people are very happy.

The parks and gardens in Marrakesh do not rely on rain. Instead, they get water from a system of underground channels that were built in the 11th century. These channels bring water from the mountains all year round. Places that are mostly dry but receive water this way are called oases.

Further south of Marrakesh, travelers reach Skoura. In Skoura, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels, and people use these squares to grow food. The snow-covered Atlas mountains in winter create a beautiful background for this area.

**Gareth Ellis**

Gareth Ellis, who is 13 years old, is the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. 

"People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time jobs in the circus. They both found jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away.

"I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving our nice house behind. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths."

"People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates."

And what about the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to important national and local newspapers, magazines, television, radio, and websites to be published. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles by our members on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three centers across the country where young people can meet and work on projects together. We plan to open more centers in the future. Since we started in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have joined us. Sophie is one of them. She says, "I first heard about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's views on hip hop music. I was amazed by the opportunities they had. Age didn't matter; we were trusted to do stories on our own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and was a member until I turned 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought I could. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee on a major news website, checking articles before they are published."

**Get Involved at Every Level**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will receive training and participate in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share their skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and older who train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they gain more experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside of Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff who go with them on these trips.

Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.

During the short summer in Antarctica, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, on a Boeing 747. These flights take you over Antarctica and then back. The exact flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be moved to a different date if needed.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**  
The average flight lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the flight, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctica will give talks about the environment and history, and they will answer your questions. There is also a camera next to the pilot that shows you the view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you will be asked to move to the seat on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have either a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an end-of-row seat for the other half. While we are over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to get up and move around the plane so everyone can enjoy the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' to give everyone a good view from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different flight plans approved. On the morning of the flight, the captain checks the satellite images of the clouds and chooses the direction with the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most wildlife in Antarctica lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we cannot see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica for environmental reasons. If you want to see wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Yes! You can bring all types of cameras. We also have some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

**Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where kids can have fun and learn to make good food.

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to share the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I was happy at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come."

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to make food for themselves when they leave home."

**Winter Driving**

Winter can be dangerous because it is hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can appear suddenly over a hill, and ice can be hidden under melting snow, making it easy to lose control of your car. A car coming towards you might slide across the road unexpectedly.

**Rule Number One** for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Quick or rough movements can make it hard to control your car. When you turn the wheel, brake, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. You can think of it like driving with a full cup of hot coffee next to you—drive carefully so you don’t spill it.

**Rule Number Two** is to pay attention to what could happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you should look. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Remember, you might be driving faster than you realize. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, three times that distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid problems.

**Craigie Aitchison**

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London to study law but decided to go to art school instead. He found the traditional drawing classes hard, but he continued to paint. In his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art, and he became interested in early Italian artists. This influence can be seen in some of his paintings. 

Aitchison loved the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the bright light there. He wanted to capture this light in his artwork. He painted by layering colors from light to dark, but he admits he never knows how it will turn out. He said, "It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top."

Like many talented artists, Aitchison makes it sound easy. He believes anyone can use colors because they can be bought. He focuses on how colors look next to each other. Unlike some artists, he does not make drawings before starting a painting. He thinks that if he draws first, he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, he often changes his paintings many times before they are done. 

He prefers to work with models who do not ask to see their pictures while he paints. He says, "If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it." Since moving to London, he has not felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He claims he is not interested in following any tradition and just paints in his own way. However, his work still inspires young British painters.

**Rock Band**

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we did not like the idea because of the noise. Ben argued, "It's better than watching TV or playing video games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the beginning. Since drums are hard to move, Ben's band members started coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours each week, our house shakes with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. 

I must admit that, even though their music can sound a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical skills—after all, I did not expect my parents to like the same music I liked when I was a teenager—but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. 

Our main worry is that they might not spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, but this has not happened yet. I always remind Ben how important his studies are. One thing is certain: Ben was right; playing music has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.

**Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private college in Wales. This college offers students important life experiences outside the classroom, along with the chance to study for their exams. The students, aged 16 to 18 and from all over the world, study in the morning. In the afternoon, they participate in useful activities, such as helping on a farm, caring for people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is that its students come from many different backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are £20,000 for two years, many students receive financial support. About a quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only attend because they get help from the government.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for encouraging international understanding among young people. You learn to live with people and respect them, even those you don’t like. During the summer holidays, my mother couldn’t believe how much less I argued with my sister."

In summary, Atlantic College provides its students with an excellent education using methods that really work.

**Being an Older Student**

At 32 years old, I have just completed my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly and have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I earned a decent salary, but I felt bored because my job did not challenge me. I became unhappy thinking that I was stuck in that job. I envied the students at the local university who seemed happy, carefree, and excited about their future. I wanted to be part of that.

Now that I am a student, I find it difficult to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel distant from the professors because, even though we are the same age, I know much less than they do. However, I am grateful for this chance to study because I understand that having a qualification is important for getting a good job.

Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending my weekends studying rather than going out to parties. I also enjoy the typical student benefits, like long holidays and discounts for theaters and cinemas. I often worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this age is a smart decision.

**Henry Ford**

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not enjoy farming. When he was fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he built his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to create affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T', which sold for $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

**Rebecca Stevens**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before climbing the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is very difficult. 

"You must carry everything on your back," she said. "You can only take what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I usually like to be clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"

When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. Now, she has written a book about her journey, and people often ask her to speak about it. She also has a new job on a science program on television. 

Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in her small flat in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains!

**CANADA GEESE**

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to find warmer weather. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds can die if they stay there. 

Last spring, a man named Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. These young birds had lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds won’t know what to do when autumn comes." He had a small plane and decided to teach the birds to follow him. 

All summer long, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese followed him. When autumn arrived and the weather got colder, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him the whole way. 

Bill left the geese in Virginia and returned home. This spring, he waited for the birds to come back, but they did not arrive. So, Bill flew back to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but could not find them. 

When he got back home, Bill was surprised to see the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without his help!

**ESTHER'S STORY**

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, but Esther decided to use her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and quickly made back her aunt's £500.

At first, Esther's parents did not want her to spend her time making jam. They thought she should study and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. But Esther did not listen to them. She continued making jam.

After a few months, she began selling her jam at the local market. Then, she started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where one of her friends worked. After two years, her business grew very large, and her parents were proud of her. She made many types of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she needed to hire some people to help her.

**Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler raise cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the wool from the sheep to keep them cool.

Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters from the wool and tried to sell them at country markets. Unfortunately, it was summer and too hot for people to buy sweaters. Instead, she decided to make socks. Everyone loved the socks because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business began.

At first, she made the socks at home, but soon she had thousands of customers. So, she started sending the wool to a factory, where machines now make all the socks. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different types of socks for walkers, sportsmen, and skiers. 

Jenny is busiest during Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In her office, she has many letters from happy customers from all over the world.

**BURGLARS PREFER THE AFTERNOON**

Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that the number of burglaries has increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also mentioned that 67% of burglaries occur when people leave their homes and forget to close a door or a window. 

Inspector Saunders explained that burglaries at night are rare because families are usually at home then. However, winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it gets dark, making it hard for them to be seen. Many houses are also empty during this time because people are still at work.

He suggested that it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This can help keep burglars away. Inspector Saunders also encouraged neighbors to watch over each other’s houses when someone is not home. They should call the police if they notice anything unusual. 

"We will also give you tips on how to make your house safe," Inspector Saunders said. "This kind of help is free."

**The History of Farming**

Before farming started, people searched in the forest for plants and fruits to eat. This meant they had to move around a lot to find food. About 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow their own food. These people were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to stay in one place, and over time, their villages grew larger. Some villagers could then do other jobs, like making clothes, because the farmers provided food for everyone. However, farming was hard, especially when the weather was bad, and some people did not have enough food to eat. Today, farmers can produce more food, and it can travel thousands of kilometers from where it is grown to our homes.

The Weather People study the weather for many reasons, and it is important for many jobs. For example, the weather is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers looked at the sky, animals, and flowers to understand the weather better. Now, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather updates on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe in old ideas about the weather. For instance, some say that if the sky is red in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from the same small town in Canada. They have always been friends and go to school together. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing and swimming on weekends. However, for the last few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. **Bollywood**

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It produces almost 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films. This is much more than the USA, making it the largest film industry in the world. Most Indians prefer watching films to any other leisure activity, and about ten million people go to the cinema every day. 

Bollywood films often tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are important parts of every movie. Indian films are also popular outside of India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. 

Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to make, while Hollywood films usually cost at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard, but they often only act for a few years. 

Amitabh Bachchan, who many consider India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in more than 140 films during his nearly 40-year acting career.

**The History of Horse Racing**

Today, horse racing is one of the most-watched sports in the USA, second only to baseball. It is also very popular in many other parts of the world.

**Parrots**

You may have seen parrots, which are beautiful birds with bright colors and long tails, in forests or zoos. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually stay in large groups and enjoy eating fruit, which can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many types of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet that help them climb and hold food. The largest parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are very loud, but they are also smart and can learn to talk easily. Some zoos have shows where you can watch parrots perform tricks they have learned.

When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he chose not to spend his money on clothes and CDs. Instead, he used his money to travel to France and eat at good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks—he says he has more than two hundred and fifty!

So, why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it is expensive to start your own restaurant and much harder to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he is sure he has made the right choice.

**John Pickering**

In a small town in central England, John Pickering cuts the grass and waters the flowers in a park. Last week, he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television. John is currently the number one singer in Japan. 

A few months ago, John visited Japan to perform in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on his radio show. Many young people called the radio station to ask for his songs to be played again. In Japan, John uses the name Jon Otis when he sings.

Despite his success, John plans to keep working in the park in England. He is not sure how much money he will make from his music. "I must keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know that he is famous in Japan and have never heard him sing.

John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This will not change the way we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

**Line Dancing**

Many people in Britain have started a new hobby called line dancing. In almost every town, you can find clubs and classes for this fun activity. 

"Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don’t need a partner because you dance in groups. It’s a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are people of all ages. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing!"

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

**The Rhino**

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough, and they have very little hair. A rhino stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. 

Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilos when it is born and stays inside its mother for around fifteen months. An adult rhino can weigh over 200 kilos and may live for up to 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, there are police officers everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police at all. A few old men tried to protect the streets at night, but they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London was growing. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, so people stayed at home as much as they could.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of people to stop the thieves. They were like police officers and were called the 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown very large and needed more police.

So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan Police Force was created with 3,000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but some rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police officers are paid well, and those who still ride horses earn even more than the others.

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people come to Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, to enjoy the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come to take part in the biggest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are filled with music and dance from morning until night. You can even see artists painting on the streets. One of the best parts of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues and cafes. Many tourists come to the Festival to watch new films, plays, and listen to famous musicians. This year, there will be over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. The tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it is often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, come to Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a place to stay, so why not book your hotel now!'

**ICE FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they try to catch fish that swim under the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years. He says, "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks, gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching fish is easy." 

First, you break the ice to make a small round hole. Then, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. You put the line through the hole and into the water. When the fish eat the bread, you pull the line up. The fish are usually between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I catch three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! 

Today, I have caught twenty-five fish! It's a great sport, and you can meet nice people here!
