**Madame Tussaud's**

One very famous place for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. Here, people can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, made wax figures of people and opened a museum in Paris. Marie helped him with this work.

In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was sent to prison. While in prison, she had to make wax copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.

BICYCLES

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. At that time, bicycles were very expensive, and only wealthy people could afford them. These early bicycles looked quite different from the ones we use today. 

As bicycles became cheaper, more people started to buy them. Many began to ride bicycles to work and for fun. Nowadays, people often use cars instead of bicycles because cars are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still choose to ride bicycles to work. They believe there are too many cars in city centers, making it hard to find parking.

**The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14**

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were excited to see the elephant show. 

We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their trainers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and started to paint on its own card. The trainers sometimes gave the elephants a new brush with paint and took away the old one. Slowly, following their trainers' instructions, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another showed a tree, and the third showed a bunch of flowers. When the trainers held up the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one.

We also gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there anymore, but the smartest elephants live in special centers where visitors can watch them.

**Big Cats**

There are many types of cats, and they vary in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats, measuring up to 3.7 meters from head to tail. While most cats dislike water, tigers often enjoy lying in pools when it is hot outside. 

Lions are unique because they live in large family groups. These groups work together to hunt for food. Lions usually inhabit flat, open areas where they can see far and easily track other animals. 

All cats have excellent eyesight, which helps them catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

THE OSTRICH

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are only a few left in the wild. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn while running. Ostriches can run very fast, between 65 and 90 kilometers an hour, making it hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens and take about 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can survive for many days without water.

Text: Victoria Jamieson is a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain. She started snowboarding at the age of 20 and has won many competitions. Last week, we talked to her at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland. We asked her why she began snowboarding. She said, "I have always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so it felt natural to try snowboarding. It’s easy to learn, and you can get really good in just a few months."

We also asked her about practice. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because it is so beautiful. But for me, free-riding—doing what you want when you’re not in a competition—is the best part."

Finally, we asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It’s also important to wear the right clothes so you don’t get wet, especially because you will fall a lot at first!"

**Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the highest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed it, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are several paths to the top, but the Marangu path, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. This path takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. 

However, only half of the climbers who attempt to reach the top succeed. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start of the climb, it can be hot and rainy, but when climbers reach the top, they find ice and snow, and the temperature can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

**Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out of their homes at night. Otters are very good swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers an hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, which allows it to stay underwater for several minutes.

Twenty years ago, there were very few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very dirty, and many fish and insects died, so otters could not find enough food. But today, there is plenty of food for them because the rivers are clean again.

**Buildings**

People have always built buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. We also have buildings like museums to display beautiful things. 

Many people work together to create a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws pictures to show their ideas. Engineers ensure that the building is strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it.

The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. However, the building looks great from all sides, not just from the top. Another well-known building is the Olympic Stadium in Munich. This interesting structure looks like a tent made of glass.

Indre, I need your help with something. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will be 80 next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is that I don’t have anything to wear. I have grown a lot, and all my trousers are too short for me now! I want to buy some new trousers and maybe some boots. I don’t have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet in the morning or the afternoon? Please let me know. Sarika

The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large picture of a man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. No one knows exactly when the Cerne Giant was created, but it is believed to be a very long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the picture. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.

**Gail Rollins**

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to compete in the 10,000 metres and maybe the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in big competitions. She always smiled and laughed, which made people in her city love her. 

Everything changed in 2004 when she ran her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with a very good time, the fastest of any British woman that year. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. However, it is not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him and he cannot keep up.

Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. She always takes a break from running on Sundays. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Piano Players - Their Early Years**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six years old. At ten, he decided he wanted to write music, and he soon began working on his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began taking lessons from a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years, and then he returned to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German, but he taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two years old, and a year later, he began playing the piano. He gave his first concert when he was six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef loved music, but he was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now, but one day he hopes to write his own music.

**Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he became a writer of children's books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she doesn't like something," says Bill. "My ten grandchildren don’t live nearby, but they also read my stories and tell me if they are good or bad." This way, Bill has learned what young children like to read.

Bill writes about life in his village and the farms around it. His fifth book is his favorite: *The Sheepdog*, which is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill, "and dogs are very clever; they learn quickly." Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest computer technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn’t change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have pictures of places like beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the pictures are often nicer than the photos people take themselves.

The first postcard was sent at the end of the 1800s. It had a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards showed images related to current events, like accidents or visits from important people. People liked these postcards because newspapers at that time did not have pictures.

Dinosaurs

No one has ever seen a dinosaur because the last one died about 60 million years ago, long before people existed on Earth. We do not know exactly why they all disappeared. The closest living relatives of dinosaurs are birds. 

Dinosaurs were not all the same; there were more than 5,000 different kinds. Some were very small, while others were huge. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast because it had long back legs.

**BEARS**

Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can kill a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well, and like most animals, they find food using their sense of smell. 

There are seven types of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in South-East Asia. Not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish-brown. 

Many people love the black and white panda bear, which comes from China. Unfortunately, not many pandas live in the forest today because it is hard for them to find food.

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in warm areas of the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water, but they can swim quickly and also move fast on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat many things, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat larger animals or people. There are more than ten different types of crocodiles, and they all have very sharp teeth. Although they lose teeth often, they quickly grow new ones. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much bigger. They can live for a long time; the oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL

In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first powered airplane and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. 

Over the next thirty years, airplanes changed a lot. In the 1950s, airplanes became much faster because they were equipped with jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was built in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world, flying at 2500 kilometers per hour, which means the trip from London to New York takes only four hours. 

Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.

The Globe Theatre

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was round and had no roof, so people could get cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, which was by the River Thames, to watch the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors would eat, talk to their friends, walk around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! 

Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre has been built in the same place near the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.

Dear Jeff,

I am having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and cold. Now, the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week, we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is very warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, and purple! Australia is very beautiful, and we don’t want to go home! I will see you at the end of September.

Sue
